data.title: Staff & Governors
data.meta_description: The highly trained staff at King's are committed to the welfare and education of all the pupils. A dedicated team made up from the best teachers around.
data.text:
George Hartley

Headmaster at King's from September 2017, Mr Hartley was previously Principal of Elizabeth College, Guernsey (2009 to 2017), Headmaster of Sixth Form at Berkhamsted School (2003 to 2009), Hertfordshire and beforehand taught at Highgate School, London and Eton College. George was educated at Cranbrook School, Kent, and St Catharine’s College, Cambridge, where he read Geography. George currently chairs the HMC Membership Committee and has carried out many HMC accreditation visits at schools across the UK. He is also a trustee of the local Platform for Life charity and is a governor at Merchant Taylor’s School, Crosby and Rudheath Senior Academy, Northwich. Married to Merewyn, he has two children, both of whom attend King’s. George is a long-suffering fan of Preston North End FC and dearly hopes that at some point during his lifetime they will reach the Premier League. His other interests include rugby, cricket, mountaineering, poetry, singing and wine. George is also a keen cook, having worked in restaurants as a young man, and knocks up a pretty mean paella.

Hayley Jordan

Hayley spent 26 years in the military leaving in the rank of Major in 2014. During her military career she served in the Ministry of Defence in London, Northern Ireland, Germany, Bosnia, Iraq and Afghanistan. After leaving the military Hayley joined Terra Nova Preparatory School in East Cheshire as their Director of Finance and Operations/Bursar, before joining King’s in January 2019. All of her roles have given her experience in strategic leadership, finance and project management; she is a Fellow of the Institute of Leadership and Management and a Member of the City and Guilds in Strategic Leadership and Management.

In her spare time Hayley enjoys socialising, cycling and walking her slightly crazy labradoodle. She is married to Jason and together they have a son called Zach.

Claire Sumner

Claire has been at King’s since 2007 and became Deputy Head Pastoral in January 2022, before taking up her new role in 2024.

Claire qualified to teach Secondary PE and Art with a BA (Hons) from Liverpool John Moores University. She taught at two local schools before joining King’s where she has held a number of pastoral and academic roles, including Head of Year, Head of House, Head of Academic PE and Assistant Head Pastoral.

As well as her teaching and pastoral roles, she played a leading role in girls’ hockey at King’s until 2019, enjoying many successes. Her highlight was taking the 1st XI to the Olympic Stadium for the 2019 ISHC Final.

Outside of school, Claire has run Cheshire Schoolgirls’ Hockey since 2007 and she has a general interest in staying active, especially Pilates and walking her dog. She is also a keen Manchester United fan and, as a Mum to two sporty teenage boys, spends much of her spare time watching them play football.

Stephen Prest

Stephen has been Deputy Head (Pastoral) since September 2024, having joined King's in January 2022 as Assistant Head Pastoral. Stephen studied Politics at the University of Essex and has subsequently read for an MA in Education Studies at Manchester Metropolitan University and an MA in International Relations at Queen Mary, University of London.

Before arriving at King's, Stephen was a Head of Year at Brentwood School in Essex and Director of Sixth Form at Rossall School on the Fylde Coast. In addition to his responsibilities at King's, Stephen will be acting as a Team Inspector for the Independent Schools Inspectorate (ISI).

Having played a lot of rugby before injuries caught up with him, Stephen is a keen Sale Sharks supporter and also enjoys cricket. Other interests include politics (which he very much continues to enjoy teaching in the Sixth Form), reading, cooking, wine, whisky and weightlifting. He lives near Chester with his partner Helen and young son.

James Millard

James has been Deputy Head (Academic) since September 2009 after being promoted from Director of Music, a post he held from the time he joined King's in 2004.

Previously, he was Director of Music at King's College School, Wimbledon, (2000-2004), Assistant Director of Music at Brentwood School (1991-1996) and a Music Teacher at Abingdon School (1996-2000). James was born in Ipswich and graduated from the University of Durham, College of St Hild & St Bede, where he read Music.

His interests include music, theatre, golf, scuba diving and skiing and he has a healthy interest in good food and fine wine.

Margaret Ainsworth

Margaret was appointed Head of Willow Lodge in January 2015 after being Deputy Head at The Queen's Lower School Chester. She joined Queen's in 2004 as Head of English having previously taught in local primary schools after changing careers from the Law to teaching. Margaret was in charge of pastoral care, safeguarding, curriculum development and a member of the Leadership Team.

Margaret introduced drama into the curriculum and was very actively involved in drama productions throughout the school. She contributed widely to the co-curricular provision and taught hockey, rounders and journalist club amongst others. Margaret's interests involve sailing, ski-ing, reading and walking the family dogs. She is married with three children.

Selena O'Donnell

After more than ten years working as a multi-media journalist for Trinity Mirror PLC, Selena joined North West Academies Trust in 2012 as Marketing Manager and helped to launch one of the first Free Schools in Chester. She continued to work with the Trust as it grew with the successful addition of other schools across the region.

She furthered her experience in education with a role as Marketing and Development Co-ordinator at The Queen’s School, Chester, before joining King’s as Marketing and Communications Manager in January 2018. She took up her current position in January 2019.

As part of her role, Selena leads on the award-winning Independent State School Partnership (ISSP), Chester Schools Together.

Her interests include cinema, reading, interior design and current affairs.

Andrea Millard

Andrea has a wealth of experience in the HR field: in her last post at Bank of America, she played a key role in the mergers and acquisitions team at legacy MBNA to Bank of America. She has experience in the retail sector, working as HR Manager at Selfridges in Manchester and London, opening the new flagship store in Trafford Centre, in addition to Boots the Chemists.

She graduated from the University of Chester with a BSc Hons in Health and Community Studies, and has her Graduate CIPD qualification. She is married with two daughters. In her spare time she likes to run and attend Zumba classes.

Bishop of Chester

Mark Tanner has been Bishop of Chester since May 2020, succeeding the Rt Revd Dr Peter Forster who retired in September 2019. He was consecrated as a Bishop at York Minster in October 2016 and was then appointed Bishop of Berwick of the Diocese of Newcastle.

He was born in Canada and educated at Loughborough Grammar School. He went on to study at Christ Church, Oxford, graduating with a Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree in 1992.

He was ordained in Chester in 1998 and both his children were born here. Following the announcement of his appointment he said “It is an honour and a joy to be appointed to the Diocese of Chester at such a key time in the life of our communities, nation, and Church.”

Dr Sandra Verity JP DL

began her varied career on Sainsbury’s Graduate training scheme after gaining her degree at Reading University. Since then she has worked primarily in business and marketing consultancy, both for and with multinational and SMEs. More recently she has run her own management consultancy business working with companies in the North West. She has combined her work life with supporting her three children through school and University. Two attended The King’s School.

She is a Governor at Chester University, a Trustee of The Chester Clergy Family Trust and a Parish Councillor.

Sandra is Chair of Governors, Chair of the Risk and Compliance Committee, and Chair of the Governance Committee.

Hayley Jordan

spent 26 years in the military leaving in the rank of Major in 2014. During her military career she served in the Ministry of Defence in London, Northern Ireland, Germany, Bosnia, Iraq and Afghanistan. After leaving the military Hayley joined Terra Nova Preparatory School in East Cheshire as their Director of Finance and Operations/Bursar, before joining King’s in January 2019. All of her roles have given her experience in strategic leadership, finance and project management; she is a Fellow of the Institute of Leadership and Management and a Member of the City and Guilds in Strategic Leadership and Management.

In her spare time Hayley enjoys socialising, cycling and walking her slightly crazy labradoodle. She is married to Jason and together they have a son called Zach.

Hayley is Clerk to the Governors.

Andrew Bentley

Andrew is Storyhouse’s founding Chief Executive and has led the charity since its foundation. He is responsible for the success of its home in Chester, which welcomes over 1m visitors per year. He also created Grosvenor Park Open Air Theatre in 2010, now the UK's pre-eminent temporary open-air theatre.

Andrew trained as a musician and was Director of Liverpool’s Philharmonic Hall, which he re-built and re-launched. He has experience in both the cultural and private sectors, having co-founded and built Liverpool’s iconic Hope Street Hotel which, along with its restaurant, has won many national awards over the years, including the industry’s award for the UK’s Best New Hotel. He is a board member of UK Theatre. Andrew was awarded a BEM in the Queen’s 2020 Birthday Honours List for services to arts and libraries.

Andrew is Vice Chair of the governors, Chair of the Finance & General Purpose Committee and Chair of the Bursary and Partnerships Policy Committee.

Debbie Leonard

Debbie trained as a teacher in Physical Education and Mathematics in Leeds and subsequently taught in six independent schools in different parts of the country. Debbie began her career as a teacher in 1988 and took on her first leadership role in January 2001. From 2001 until August 2021, she held four senior leader roles, the last two being headships. The last headship role was at The Grange School, Hartford.

Debbie has been an ISI team inspector since 2007 and been a governor in a number of schools. Since September 2021, she has moved into Executive and Senior Leader coaching and educational consultancy.

Away from school, Debbie has a passion for all sports and outdoor activities. Her particular interest is in hockey and she has been a premier league coach for three top ladies’ teams in England.

Debbie is Vice Chair of the Governors, Chair of Education Committee and also the nominated governor for PSHE and RSE.

Andrew Bartley

At a young age, Andrew moved primary school to The King's School in Chester and stayed there for the rest of his school career. He then went to University in Manchester to study maths. He moved on to law at Christleton for his conversion and LPC and qualified as a Solicitor, gaining Higher Rights of Audience very soon after qualification. He then became a Fellow of the Chartered Institute of Arbitrators as well as sitting as a part time Judge.

Having been ranked for a number of years as a Leading Individual in the North West by Legal500 for Commercial Litigation, he retired from private practice and he is now a full time Judge in Manchester. He is married to Olivia, who works for the NHS, and has two children.

Andrew is a member of the Bursaries and Partnerships Policy Committee.

John Ebo

John Ebo has lived in Chester for some forty years, is married with two sons who are currently at university undertaking post-graduate and under-graduate studies respectively.

A former Lord Mayor of the City of Chester and first Chairman of Cheshire West and Chester Council, he served on the local councils for some three decades with responsibilities including Chairman of Environmental Service Committee and, later, Chairman of the Licensing Board. He has served as a Governor of a number of local schools, both Primary and Secondary, and is currently vice-Chairman of Newton Primary School Governors. He has extensive experience of the appointment of all levels of teaching and non-teaching staff.

In business he ran a successful Mortgage Brokerage working within the residential and commercial sectors. He has retired from this business and currently writes and speaks on Local Government.

John is a member of the Risk and Compliance Committee and is the Health and Safety Governor.

Carol Edwards

trained to be a Probation Officer at Liverpool University and subsequently worked for Cheshire Probation Service in the criminal courts, and for CAFCASS in the family courts. After taking early retirement in 2009, she studied for a BA in English Literature at Chester University; this was followed by an MA and a lecturing post at Chester University.

She is a member of an independent ethics committee at Unilever and is a trustee of the Robert Oldfield Trust. When her children were at school, she was a parent governor at their infant, junior and secondary schools. She was appointed to the Board of Governors at King’s as a nominative governor in June 2017.

Carol is Chair of the Safeguarding Committee and is the staff liaison governor.

David Rowlands

David farms Red Poll beef on the family farm in Mickle Trafford with his wife and son.

He chairs the Oldfield Educational Trust, and is a director of the farming charity, the Addington Fund. He is a Governor at two State schools, and is a former Chester City and Cheshire County Councillor. He was appointed to the Board of Governors at King’s as a nominative governor in June 2017.

David is a member of the Finance & General Purpose Committee.

Mike Sayer

Mike was born and raised in Chester, and attended King’s from 1995 to 2002. After graduating with a first class degree in Mechanical Engineering from Imperial College London, Mike joined Bentley’s Engineering team. He subsequently worked in their Communications team and is now Head of Product Communications with a global responsibility. In early 2021, Mike also took on responsibility for the Bentley Heritage Collection – a fleet of 45 cars that, together, represent Bentley’s entire 104-year history.

Outside work, Mike enjoys fitness training, landscape photography and spending time with his family – Natasha (also a King’s alumna) and two children, Holly and Sebastian.

Mike is a member of the Education Committee.

The Very Reverend Dr Tim Stratford

was ordained deacon in 1986, and priest in 1987.[4] After curacies in Mossley Hill and St Helens he was chaplain to David Sheppard, Bishop of Liverpool from 1991 to 1994. He was vicar of West Derby from 1994 to 2003 and Team Rector of Kirkby until 2012. He was Archdeacon of Leicester until his installation as Dean of Chester on 8 September 2018.

The Very Reverend Dr Stratford is a member of the Education Committee.

Madeleine Troy

Madeleine grew up in Chester and attended The Queen’s School. Prior to reading History at University College London, Madeleine took a gap year, and fulfilled a childhood dream of qualifying as a ski instructor in Mammoth, California.

Madeleine then went on to study for a masters degree in Real Estate at The University of Reading, and subsequently qualified as a chartered surveyor in London. She has spent most of her career working client-side, in the food retail industry.

She has recently returned to live in Chester and currently heads up the estates function across UK & Ireland for a global sweet treat brand.

In her spare time, Madeleine is an avid cook, likes to travel, spend time in the countryside and attend classic car events.

Madeleine is a member of the Finance & General Purpose Committee and the Risk and Compliance Committee.
